name: blog_os
description: Writing an OS in Rust
interact_justification: We use the normal GitHub workflow (issues and pull requests). Each blog post also mentions this at the beginning, e.g. https://os.phil-opp.com/freestanding-rust-binary/
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
contribution_requirements_justification: Since this is a learning project, most contributions only correct minor things (e.g. typos). We never closed a possible contribution because it wasn't "acceptable".
license_location_justification:
https://github.com/phil-opp/blog_os/blob/master/LICENSE-MIT
https://github.com/phil-opp/blog_os/blob/master/LICENSE-APACHE
floss_license_justification: All the code is dual licensed under MIT/APACHE2, which is mentioned in the READMEs (e.g. https://github.com/phil-opp/blog_os/tree/post-10#license).
documentation_basics_justification:
The blog at https://os.phil-opp.com/ explains every single line of the projet.

Additionally, the README for each post provides basic build and run instructions, e.g. ar https://github.com/phil-opp/blog_os/tree/post-10#building
documentation_interface_justification: The software is an OS kernel, which takes no input. The output is frequently shown on the blog, e.g. at https://os.phil-opp.com/minimal-rust-kernel/#booting-it-in-qemu
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Each change has an unique commit id. We distribute only source code (no binaries).
version_semver_justification: No semver releases, since this is a learning project
version_tags_justification: Each new post uses a separate `post-XX` branch for its code.
release_notes_justification: No real releases. Each new post at https://os.phil-opp.com/ describes the full set of changes.
release_notes_vulns_justification: We're not creating any software that is used in production, we just create a tutorial how to create a small toy OS.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Only a toy OS tutorial, no real vulnerabilities possible.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Only a toy OS tutorial, no real vulnerabilities possible.
test_most_justification: We try our best to test our kernel through unit and integration tests
test_policy_justification: We try to add tests for each new post that adds new functionality.
warnings_justification: We use the strict Rust compiler
warnings_fixed_justification: No (unintentional) warnings should occur when compiling the project
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: mockolo
description: Mockolo is a mock generator for Swift. Swift doesn't provide mocking support, and Mockolo provides a fast and easy way to autogenerate mock objects that can be tested in your code. One of the main objectives of Mockolo is performance. Unlike other frameworks, Mockolo provides highly performant and scalable generation of mocks via a lightweight commandline tool, so it can run as part of a linter or during a build if one chose to do so. Try Mockolo and enhance your project's test coverage in an efficient, performant way.
description_good_justification: Mockolo is a mock generator for Swift. Swift doesn't provide mocking support, and Mockolo provides a fast and easy way to autogenerate mock objects that can be tested in your code. One of the main objectives of Mockolo is performance. Unlike other frameworks, Mockolo provides highly performant and scalable generation of mocks via a lightweight commandline tool, so it can run as part of a linter or during a build if one chose to do so. Try Mockolo and enhance your project's test coverage in an efficient, performant way.
interact_justification: https://github.com/uber/mockolo/blob/master/README.md#report-any-issues shows how to file an issue or provide feedback.  https://github.com/uber/mockolo/blob/master/README.md#how-to-contribute-to-mockolo shows how to contribute to the project.
contribution_justification: https://github.com/uber/mockolo/blob/master/README.md#how-to-contribute-to-mockolo shows the workflow and other relevant info.
contribution_requirements_justification: It includes https://github.com/raywenderlich/swift-style-guide for standard swift style guide along with guiding principles and workflow.

documentation_basics_justification: https://gitlab.com/GCSBOSS/nodecaf#readme

warnings_strict_justification: Not sure how to evidence it
static_analysis_often_justification: GitLab CI runs it automatically on every commit.
dynamic_analysis_justification:
We have a 100% branch coverage automated test suite.
https://gitlab.com/GCSBOSS/nodecaf/-/blob/master/test/spec.js
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: It's a NodeJS framework. So it's memory-safe.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
We have assertions and type checkings all over the code. 
We have a 100% statement coverage automated test suite.
discussion_justification: https://gitlab.com/GCSBOSS/nodecaf/issues
crypto_tls12_justification: We provide standard NodeJS HTTPS functionality.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: We use standard NodeJS HTTPS functionality.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: We use standard NodeJS HTTPS functionality.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
internationalization_justification: The framework is directed to back-end apps that don't necessarily interact directly with humans. So it's the responsibility of the authors using Nodecaf to ensure their final software produces internationalized output.
sites_password_security_justification: The "website" currently is just the GitLab project page.
maintenance_or_update_justification:
All relevant releases of the project can be found in this URL: https://gitlab.com/GCSBOSS/nodecaf/-/releases
Also since the project is currently not 1.0 most interface changes are only mentioned. Whenever the interface becomes more stable the necessary guidance on the upgrade will be in the release notes for each version.
build_standard_variables_justification: It's an interpreted code framework with no native dependencies.
build_preserve_debug_justification: It's an interpreted code framework with no native dependencies.
build_non_recursive_justification: It's an interpreted code framework with no native dependencies.
build_repeatable_justification: It's an interpreted code framework with no native dependencies.
dependency_monitoring_justification: Dependencies are checked on every commit and their security status can be found here: https://gitlab.com/GCSBOSS/nodecaf/-/dependencies
updateable_reused_components_justificati: NPM takes care of dependencies updating and vulnerability detection
interfaces_current_justification: All external dependencies are actively maintained.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: All released versions have measured 100% test coverage.
test_statement_coverage90_justification: Any contribution is required 100% code coverage before being accepted. The current code coverage is 100%.
test_branch_coverage80_justification: Any contribution is required 100% code coverage before being accepted. The current code coverage is 100%. Even for branching.

name: Siddhi
description:
Siddhi is a cloud native Streaming and Complex Event Processing engine that understands Streaming SQL queries in order to capture events from diverse data sources, process them, detect complex conditions, and publish output to various endpoints in real time.

Siddhi can run as an embedded Java library, and as a microservice on bare metal, VM, Docker and natively in Kubernetes. It also has a graphical and text editor for building Streaming Data Integration and Streaming Analytics applications.
sites_https_justification:
Given only https: URLs.
https://github.com/siddhi-io
https://siddhi.io/
interact_justification:
Necessary details on how the community can contribute to the project is available. 
https://siddhi.io/community/
https://siddhi.io/community/contribution/
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as https://siddhi.io/community/contribution/ ..
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/siddhi-io/siddhi/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
Handled through github issues and projects.
https://github.com/siddhi-io/siddhi/issues
https://github.com/orgs/siddhi-io/projects
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There is no any public known vulnerabilities. https://github.com/siddhi-io/siddhi/releases
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No issues are reported through security@wso2.com or dev mailing lists yet.
test_justification:
It is implemented on top of Testng. 
https://github.com/siddhi-io/siddhi/blob/master/modules/siddhi-core/src/test/resources/testng.xml
test_invocation_justification:
Build is depend on maven. Tests are written in Testng. Can be done with simple maven command "mvn test" .

https://siddhi.io/en/v5.1/development/build/
https://github.com/siddhi-io/siddhi/blob/master/modules/siddhi-core/src/test/resources/testng.xml
test_most_justification:
Code coverage is around 67% at the moment.
https://codecov.io/gh/siddhi-io/siddhi
test_policy_justification: Tests and test coverage are required for any PRs. It is verified with the codecov integration for each PR.
tests_are_added_justification: We do not allow any changes to master without the code changes having test coverage. It is verified with the codecov integration for each PR.
tests_documented_added_justification: It is part of PR template process - https://github.com/siddhi-io/siddhi/blob/master/pull_request_template.md
warnings_justification: Default Java warn flags are used. Other than that, Find bug is integrated with the code base.
crypto_call_justification: Transport implementation are depend on OpenSSL wherever required.
crypto_keylength_justification: Any key length is supported, user provided certificates.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Passwords can be encrypted through the user provided key store certs. Then, it totally depends on the user provided certs.
crypto_random_justification: We are using Java's java.security.SecureRandom for random number generation.
delivery_mitm_justification:
https://siddhi.io/en/v5.1/download/
https://siddhi.io/en/v5.1/development/

We are also publishing md5, sha-1 and asc details to verify the download.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j:
Checkstyle and FInabug contain commonly accepted rules and we are aligned to that.

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/wso2/code-quality-tools/v1.2/checkstyle/checkstyle.xml
static_analysis_often_justification: FIndbug & Checkstyle runs every build. Veracode for each release.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Yes, Qualys tool is used for this purpose.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: It is must and part of the process to respond/fix to the vulnerabilities reported through the static/dynamic scans.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: Default keystores that are shipped with the runtime contains certificates with are based on SHA256withRSA encryption. Users can change the certificates as they wish. Also wee utilize all the top recommended ciphers for TLS 1.2+.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
Yes, it is fully automated with Travis, Appveyor & Jenkins. 
http://travis-ci.org/siddhi-io/siddhi
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/WSO2/siddhi/
https://wso2.org/jenkins/view/wso2-dependencies/job/siddhi/job/siddhi/
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: OpenLearnr
description: Open Source Course Management Platform
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/blob/develop/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The AGPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We use fully automated deployment (Travis CI based https://travis-ci.org/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/builds/556946034) with GitHub releases (https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/releases) which supports discussion. Also the versions are semvar (https://semver.org/) so each patch or minor release will be visible and subject to discussion.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_tags_justification: We use semantic versioning with Gihub Releases and Tags; https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/releases
release_notes_justification: Github Releases (with summary for human readable content) and Tags are being used; https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/releases
release_notes_vulns_justification: We use dependabot and also patch vulnerabilities as they arise. Example: https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/releases
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: We use full disclosure; all vulnerabilities and security issues are reported through our issues section (https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/issues)
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: We use Github Alerts with Dependabot support and quickly fix critical vulnerabilities. For example; https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/releases/tag/v1.3.4
test_justification: Spring Test Context Framework (https://docs.spring.io/spring/docs/current/spring-framework-reference/testing.html) is used for integration tests, and Jest (https://jestjs.io/) is used for UI tests. Further information about complete testing suit can be found in our generator documentation; https://www.jhipster.tech/running-tests/
test_invocation_justification: Maven and npm is used; more information can be found at our documentation; https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/blob/master/docs/DEVELOPER_DOCUMENTATION.md
test_most_justification: We try to maintain code coverage to an acceptable level; https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=com.asanka.tutor%3Aopen-learnr
tests_are_added_justification: Try to add tests with each new functionality; for example https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/commit/aa9092fee058bb015ef44b8b17af1190e8538af2
tests_documented_added_justification: We have test policy document at, https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/blob/master/docs/CONTRIBUTING.md
warnings_justification:
We user Sonar for code quality analysis;

https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/blob/master/docs/DEVELOPER_DOCUMENTATION.md#code-quality and TSLint for front end code quality analysis; https://palantir.github.io/tslint/. Out TSLint file is; https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/blob/master/tslint.json
warnings_fixed_justification: This is automatically kept at a healthy state by SonarQube.
warnings_strict_justification: This is automatically kept at a healthy state by SonarQube.
crypto_published_justification:
Application base is generated from JHipster (https://www.jhipster.tech/) and we do not override or customize our own cryptographic protocols. Thus everything JHipster has to offer is inherited. 

https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/2159#security

Application base is generated from JHipster (https://www.jhipster.tech/) and we do not override or customize our own cryptographic protocols. Thus everything JHipster has to offer is inherited.

delivery_unsigned_justification: If you follow our documentation above, this is not possible as you use TLS
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We have Sonar Analysis for this; https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=com.asanka.tutor%3Aonline-tutor
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We constantly monitor Sonar (https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=com.asanka.tutor%3Aonline-tutor); after each commit to master branch.
static_analysis_often_justification: Yes, we do this automatically through our Travis Build (https://travis-ci.org/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr)
dynamic_analysis_justification: Underlying generator (JHipster) uses OWASP with each major release.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: No memory unsafe languages are used; Java and Typescript are the primary languages used in this project.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Underlying generator (JHipster) uses OWASP with each major release.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We do this through Github Alerts and Dependabot; example https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr/releases/tag/v1.3.4
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
Application base is generated from JHipster (https://www.jhipster.tech/) and we do not override or customize our own cryptographic protocols. Thus everything JHipster has to offer is inherited. 

https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/2159#security
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Only sample credentials which can be used by other developers and contributors are uploaded to Github and all production credentials are kept privately.
english_justification: Add documentation provided in the Github repo as well as any associated website/link is in English (https://github.com/python-sinhala-education-society/OpenLearnr)
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
